Title: Verse 6598
Verse: 6598
Sanskrit: तस्मिन् व्रजति दुर्धर्षे प्रास्खलद् रुक्मिणी पथि। तन्नामर्षयत श्रीमांस्ततस्तूर्णमचोदयत्॥
English: Therefore with all care entertain guests. O king, those that give to his guests water to wash his feet, butter to rub over his tired legs, light in darkness and food and shelter, do not (at all) go before Yama.

Title: Verse 6599
Verse: 6599
Sanskrit: ततः परमसंक्रुद्धो रथात् प्रस्कन्ध स द्विजः। पदातिरुत्पथेनैव प्राद्रवद् दक्षिणामुखः॥
English: The removal of garlands of flowers offered to the gods, the removal of the remnant of a Brahmana's food, serving with prepared pastes, the shampooing of a Brahmana's legs, O foremost of kings, each of these gives better fruits than the giving away of kine.

Title: Verse 6600
Verse: 6600
Sanskrit: तमत्पथेन धावन्तमन्वधावं द्विजोत्तमम्। तथैव पायसादिग्धः प्रसीद भगवन्निति॥
English: A man certainly rescues himself (from hell) by giving away Kapila cow, therefore a Kapila cow, decked with ornaments, should be given to a Brahmana.

Title: Verse 6601
Verse: 6601
Sanskrit: ततो विलोक्य तेजस्वी ब्राह्मणो मामुवाच ह। जितः क्रोधस्त्वया कृष्ण प्रकृत्यैव महाभुज॥
English: One should make gifts to a person nobly born, one who is learned in the Vedas, one that is fair, one who leads a domestic life, but who is burdened with wife and children, one who duly worships the sacred fire and one who has done you no service.

Title: Verse 6602
Verse: 6602
Sanskrit: न तेऽपराधमिह वै दृष्टवानस्मि सुव्रत। प्रीतोऽस्मि तव गोविन्द वृणु कामान् यथेप्सितान्।।३८
English: O best of the Bharata race, O descendant of Bharata, you should always give away to such men and not to those who are wealthy. What merit is there to give (wealth) to one who is wealthy?

Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6603
Verse: 6603
Sanskrit: प्रसन्नस्य च मे तात पश्य व्युष्टिं यथाविधि। यावदेव मनुष्याणामन्ने भावो भविष्यति॥ यथैवान्ने तथा तेषां त्वयि भावो भविष्यति। यावच्च पुण्या लोकेषु त्वयि कीर्तिर्भविष्यति॥
English: One cow must be given to one Brahmana. One single cow must not be given to many Brahmanas. If that cow is sold, three generations of the giver's family would be lost. Such a gift will neither rescue the giver nor the Brahmana who takes it.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6604
Verse: 6604

English: He who gives away eighty Ratis of pure gold, obtains the everlasting fruit of giving away one hundred pieces of gold.

Verse: 6605

Title: Verse 6607
Verse: 6607
Sanskrit: न तु पादतले लिप्ते कस्मात्ते पुत्रकाद्य वै। नैतन्मे प्रियमित्येवं स मां प्रीतोऽब्रवीत् तदा॥ इत्युक्तोऽहं शरीरं स्वं ददर्श श्रीसमायुतम्।
English: The tired traveller, with weakened limbs and with feet besmeared with dust, asks for the name of him who gives him food. There are men who answer him by telling him the name. That wise man who informs the toil-worn travellers the name of the persons who give them food is certainly considered equal in virtue as the giver of food himself.

Title: Verse 6608
Verse: 6608
Sanskrit: रुक्मिणी चाब्रवीत् प्रीत: सर्वस्त्रीणां वरं यश:।४५ कीर्ति चानुत्तमां लोके समवाप्स्यसि शोभने।
English: O Yudhishthira, Therefore (even) abstaining from other kinds of gifts, give away food. There is no virtue so great as that of giving well-cooked and pure food to the Brahmanas according to one's ability. That man by his this act obtains the companionship of Prajapati.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6609
Verse: 6609
Sanskrit: न त्वां जरा वा रोगो वा वैवयं चापि भाविनि।।४६ स्प्रक्ष्यन्ति पुण्यगन्धा च कृष्णमाराधयिष्यसि।
English: There is no gift superior to that of food. The food is the foremost and the first of all things. It is said that food is Prajapati. Prajapati (again) is considered as year and the year is sacrifice.

English: From sacrifice all mobile and immobile creatures take their birth. For this reason it has been heard by us that food is the foremost of all things.

Title: Verse 6618
Verse: 6618
Sanskrit: एवं व्युष्टिमहं प्राप्तो ब्राह्मणस्य प्रसादजाम्। यच्च मामाह भीष्मोऽयं तत्सत्यं भरतर्षभ॥
English: The way is over space. There is no water there and it is terrible to look at. There is nowhere in that region any shade of any tree, any water and any resting place, in which the traveller when fatigued, may take rest for some time.

Title: Verse 6626

English: O son of Pandu, those that have fasted for six nights, go on cars drawn by peacocks. English: O king of kings, worship there these (Brahmanas) in all due form. Weakened with travelling and besmeared with the dust on this way, the traveller asks for the name of him who gives food and comes in hope to his house to worship him with all care, for he is a great Brahmana.

Sanskrit: षड्वक्त्रस्य तु माहात्म्यं कुक्कुटस्य तु साधनम् शक्त्या देव्याः साधनं च तथा पारिषदामपि॥ विश्वामित्रश्चाकारैतत् कर्म लोकहिताय वै। तस्मादृषिः कुमारस्य विश्रामित्रोऽभवत् प्रियः॥

Title: Verse 6631
Verse: 6631

Title: Verse 6632
Verse: 6632
Sanskrit: मार्कण्डेय उवाच स्कन्दं श्रुत्वा तदा देवा वासवं सहिताऽब्रुवन्॥ अविषाबलं स्कन्दं जहि शक्राशु माचिरम्। यदि वा न निहंस्येनं देवेन्द्रोऽयं भविष्यति॥ त्रैलोक्यं संनिगृह्यास्मांस्त्वां च शक्र महाबल।
English: Yudhishthira said : O lord, O virtuous man, I desire to hear you again and again on sacred subjects relating to virtue and morals.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6633
Verse: 6633
Sanskrit: स तानुवाच व्यथितो बालोऽयं सुमहाबलः॥ स्रष्टारमपि लोकानां युधि विक्रम्य नाशयेत्। न बालमुत्सहे हन्तुभिति शक्रः प्रभाषते॥
English: Markandeya said: O king, I shall now speak on another sacred subject relating to eternity which destroys all sins. Listen to me with all others.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6634
Verse: 6634
Sanskrit: तेऽब्रुवन् नास्ति ते वीर्यं यत् एवं प्रभाषसे। सर्वास्त्वद्याभिगच्छन्तु स्कन्दं लोकस्य मातरः॥ कामवीर्या जन्तु चैनं तथेत्युक्त्वा च ता ययुः।
English: O best of the Bharata race, the merit equal to that of giving away a Kapila cow in Pushkara (Tirtha) is obtained by washing the feet of the Brahmanas.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6635
Verse: 6635
Sanskrit: तमप्रतिबलं दृष्ट्वा विषण्णवदनास्तु ताः॥ अशक्योऽयं विचन्त्यैवं तमेव शरणं ययुः। ऊचुश्चैनं त्वमस्माकं पुत्रो भव महाबल॥
English: As long as the earth remains moist with the water touched by the feet of a Brahmana, so long do the Pitris drink water from the lotus leaves.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6636
Verse: 6636
Sanskrit: अभिनन्दस्व नः सर्वाः प्रस्नुताः स्नेहविक्लवाः। तासां तद् वचनं श्रुत्वा पातुकाम: स्तनान् प्रभुः॥ ताः सम्पूज्य महासेन: कामांश्चासां प्रदाय सः। अपश्यदग्निमायान्तं पितरं बलिनां बली॥
English: If a guest is welcomed, Agni is gratified. If he is offered a seat, Indra is gratified. If his feet are washed, it is the Pitris who are delighted. If he is fed, it is Prajapati (Brahma) himself who is gratified.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6637
Verse: 6637
Sanskrit: स तु सम्पूजजितस्तेन सह मातृगणेन ह। परिवार्य महासेनं रक्षमाणः स्थितः शिवः॥
English: One should with subdued soul give away a cow when the feet and the head of her calf are visible. Before her delivery is complete, a cow with her calf in the air in the course of falling from the uterus to the earth is to be considered as equal to the earth herself.

English: O Yudhishthira, he is adored in the celestials region as many thousand Yugas as there are hairs on the bodies of that cow and the calf.

English: The person who donets a black cow duly ornamented with jwels including nose-ring made of gold and the hoof made of silver.

Title: Verse 6640
Verse: 6640
Sanskrit: संजय उवाच तद् बलं सुमहद् दीर्णं त्वदीयं प्रेक्ष्य वीर्यवान्। दधारैको रणे राजन् वृषसेनोऽस्त्रमायया॥
English: O descendant of Bharata, he who, having accepted a gift, gives it away immediately to a person who is virtuous and honest, obtains great merit. He certainly obtains the fruit of giving away the whole earth to her utmost limits with her oceans, seas and caves, her mountains and forests and woods.

English: The Brahmana, who eats in silence from a plate, keeping his hands between his knees, succeeds in saving others.

Title: Verse 6642
Verse: 6642
Sanskrit: तस्य दीप्ता महाबाणा विनिश्चेरुः सहस्रशः। भानोरिव महाराज धर्मकाले मरीचयः॥
English: Those Brahmanas who abstain from drink and who are never spoken by others as having any fault and who daily read the Samhitas are capable of saving others,

Title: Verse 6643
Verse: 6643
Sanskrit: तेनार्दिता महाराज रथिनः सादिनस्तथा। निपेतुरुवा॒ सहसा वातभग्ना इव द्रुमाः॥
English: Havya (libation of ghee) and Kavya (edible offerings) should all be presented to a Brahmana who is learned in the Vedas. As an offering of ghee to Agnis is never in vain, so a gift to the Brahmanas learned in the Vedas is never in vain.

English: The Brahinanas have anger as their weapon; they never fight with weapons made of iron or steel. The Brahmanas kill their enemies with anger, as the wielder of thunder killed the Asuras.

Title: Verse 6649
Verse: 6649
Sanskrit: छादयन्तो महाराज द्रोपदेयान् महारथान्। शरैर्नानाविधै स्तूर्णं पर्वताञ्जलदा इव॥
English: That Brahmana who adores (the goddess) Sandhya in the morning and in the evening and who recites the sacred Gayatri, who is the mother of the Vedas, is cleansed from all his sins after being sanctified by the latter. English: Those planets in the sky including the sun that may be inauspicious and hostile towards him soon become favourable and auspicious towards him for his these acts. And those that are auspicious and favourable become more auspicious and favourable.

Title: Verse 6661
Verse: 6661
Sanskrit: द्रोणं निवारितं दृष्ट्वा कुमारेण द्विजर्षभम्। सिंहनादरवो ह्यासीत् साधु साध्विति भाषितम्॥
English: Carrying of the three stays, the vow of silence, matted locks (on head), shaving of the head, wearing barks and deer skins, observing vows, practicing ablutions, worshipping of fire and living in the forest emaciating the body, all these are useless to one if his heart be not pure.
---

Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6662
Verse: 6662
Sanskrit: कुमारस्तु ततो द्रोणं सायकेन महाहवे। विव्याधोरसि संक्रुद्धः सिंहवच्च नदन् मुहुः॥
English: O king of kings, the indulgence of the six senses is (very) easy if purity be not its aim. Abstinence is itself difficult to acquire and it is more so if purity be not its aim. Among all the senses mind is the most dangerous.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6663
Verse: 6663
Sanskrit: संवार्य च रणे द्रोणं कुमारस्तु महाबलः। शरैरनेकसाहौः कृतहस्तो जितश्रमः॥
English: These high-souled, men who do not commit sin in word, in deed, in heart or in soul, are said (really) to perform asceticism; but not those who make their bodies emaciated by fasts and penances.
---
Source: Itihasa

Title: Verse 6664
Verse: 6664
Sanskrit: तं शूरमार्यव्रतिनं मन्त्रास्त्रेषु कृतश्रमम्। चक्ररक्षं परामृनात् कुमारं द्विजपुङ्गवः॥
English: He who has no feeling of kindness for his relatives even if his body be pure cannot be free from sin. That hard-heartedness of his mind is his great enemy to asceticism.

English: He who is always pure, who is endued with virtue and who practice virtue all his life, even if he leads a domestic life, is a (real) Rishi. He is freed from all sins.

Title: Verse 6667
Verse: 6667
Sanskrit: व्यक्षोभयद् रणे योधान् यथा मुख्यमभिद्रवन्। अभ्यवर्तत सम्प्रेप्सुः कुन्तीपुत्रं युधिष्ठिरम्॥
English: The man whose heart is without holiness suffers torture by undergoing penances only being ignorant of their meaning. He is never freed from sins of such acts. The fire he worships does not consume his sins.

Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6668
Verse: 6668
Sanskrit: युगन्धरस्ततो राजन् भारद्वाजं महारथम्। वारयामास संक्रुद्धं वातोद्धतमिवार्णवम्॥
English: Through holiness and virtue alone men can go to the regions of bliss and their vows and fasts can become efficacious. Living on fruits and roots, observing the vow of silence, living on air, shaving one's head, abandoning a fixed home, having matted locks on head, lying under the sky, observing daily fasts, worshipping the fire, bathing in water and lying on the ground, these alone cannot lead one to heaven.
---
Source: Itihasa

Title: Verse 6669
Verse: 6669
Sanskrit: युधिष्ठिरं स विद्ध्वा तु शरैः संनतपर्वभिः। युगन्धरं तु भल्लेन रथनीडादपातयत्॥
English: Those only that are endued with holiness succeed by knowledge and by (virtuous) deeds to conquer disease, decrepitude and death and they alone obtain a very high state.

Source: Itihasa

Title: Verse 6670
Verse: 6670
Sanskrit: ततो विराटद्रुपदौ केकया: सात्यकिः शिबिः। व्याघ्रदत्तश्च पाञ्चाल्य: सिंहसेनश्च वीर्यवान्॥ एते चान्ये च बहवः परीप्सन्तो युधिष्ठिरम्। आवब्रुस्तस्य पन्थानं किरन्तः सायकान् बहून्॥
English: As seeds that have been scorched by fire do not produce the plant, so the pains that have been burnt by knowledge cannot affect the soul.

Source: Itihasa

Title: Verse 6671
Verse: 6671
Sanskrit: व्याघ्रदत्तस्तुपाञ्चाल्योद्रोणं विव्याघ मार्गणैः। पञ्चाशता शितै राजंस्तत उच्चुक्रुशुर्जनाः॥
English: The inert body, which is like a block of wood when destitute of soul, is certainly very short-lived like the forth in the ocean.

Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6672
Verse: 6672
Sanskrit: त्वरितं सिंहसेनस्तु द्रोण विद्ध्वा महारथम्। प्राहसत् सहसा हृष्टस्त्रासयन् व महारथान्॥
English: He who obtains a view of his soul that dwells within every one's body by the help of one or the half of a rhythmic line (of the Vedas) has no need for anything else.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6673
Verse: 6673
Sanskrit: ततो विस्फार्य नयने धनुर्ध्यामवमृज्य च। तलशब्दं महत् कृत्वा द्रोणस्तं समुपाद्रवत्॥
English: Some, by obtaining a knowledge of the identity of the supreme soul from but two letters (of the Vedas) and some, from hundreds and thousands of slokas, acquire salvation; for the knowledge of one's identity with the supreme soul is the sure sign of salvation.

Title: Verse 6674
Verse: 6674
Sanskrit: ततस्तु सिंहसेनस्य शिरः कायात् सकुण्डलम्। व्याघ्रदत्तस्य चाक्रम्य भल्लाभ्यामाहरबली॥
English: The learned old men have said that neither this world, nor that hereafter, nor bliss can come to one who is full of doubts. Faith is the certain sign of salvation.

Title: Verse 6675
Verse: 6675
Sanskrit: तान् प्रमथ्य शरवातैः पाण्डवानां महारथान्। युधिष्ठिररथाभ्याशे तस्थौ मृत्युरिवान्तकः॥
English: He who knows the true meaning of the Vedas also understands their true use. He is frightened at the Vedic rites as man at a conflagration.

Title: Verse 6676
Verse: 6676
Sanskrit: ततोऽभवन्महाशब्दो राजन् यौधिष्ठिरे बले। हतो राजेति योधानां समीपस्थे यतव्रते॥
English: Abandoning dry discussion, take to Smriti and Shruti. Seek with the help of your reason the knowledge of the undying one who is without a second. One's search (for a thing) becomes in vain from the defect of means.

Title: Verse 6677
Verse: 6677
Sanskrit: अब्रुवन् सैनिकास्तत्र दृष्ट्वा द्रोणस्य विक्रमम्। अद्य राजा धार्तराष्ट्रः कृतार्थो वै भविष्यति॥
English: Therefore one should carefully try to obtain knowledge by means of the Vedas. The Vedas are the supreme soul, they are his body, they are the truth. The soul, that is bound by the animal organism belonging to a man in whom all the Vedas are manifest, can (only) know Him.
---
Source: Itihasa

Title: Verse 6678

Sanskrit: अस्मिन् मुहूर्ते द्रोणस्तु पाण्डवं गृह्य हर्षितः। आगमिष्यति नो नूनं धार्तराष्ट्रस्य संयुगे॥
English: The existence of the celestials as stated in the Vedas, the efficacy of (religious) acts and the capacity for action of beings furnished with bodies are noticeable in every Yuga.

English: Independence from and the annihilation of these are to be sought by means of the purity of the senses. Therefore the suspension of the function of the senses is the true fasting.

Title: Verse 6683
Verse: 6683
Sanskrit: न दिशो नान्तरिक्षं च न द्यौर्नेव च मेदिनी। अदृश्यन्त महाराज बाणभूता इवाभवन्॥
English: Hear about the mysteries of charity as they have been expounded in the Shrutis and Smritis. O Yudhishthira, he who performs a Shraddha in the conjunction of Gajachhaya at a place fanned by the leaves of an Ashvattha tree enjoys its fruits one hundred thousand Kalpas.

Title: Verse 6684
Verse: 6684
Sanskrit: नादृश्यत तदा राजंस्तत्र किंचन संयुगे। बाणान्धकारे महति कृते गाण्डीवधन्वना॥
English: O ruler of earth, he who gives food to one who is dying of hunger and he who founds a home of charity with a person to look after it both acquire the fruits of (performing) all sacrifices.

Title: Verse 6685
Verse: 6685
Sanskrit: सूर्ये चास्तमनुप्राप्ते तमसा चाभिसंवृते। नाज्ञायत तदा शत्रुर्न सुहन च कश्चन॥
English: He who gives away a horse at a Tirtha where the current of the water runs in an opposite direction obtains merits that are inexhaustible. A guest who comes for food is Indra himself. If he is entertained with food, Indra confers on the feeder merits that are inexhaustible. As men cross rivers and seas by boats, so is he saved from all his sins (by giving board to guests).

Title: Verse 6686
Verse: 6686
Sanskrit: ततोऽवहारं चक्रुस्ते द्रोणदुर्योधनादयः। तान् विदित्वा पुनस्त्रस्तानयुद्धमनसः परान्॥
English: Therefore what is given to the Brahmanas produces, like the gift of curds, inexhaustible merits. A gift on a particular festive day produces twice the merit and on a particular season produces ten times the merit.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6687
Verse: 6687
Sanskrit: स्वान्यनीकानि बीभत्सुः शनकैरवहारयत्। ततोऽभितुष्टुवुः पार्थे प्रहृष्टाः पाण्डुसंजयाः॥ पञ्चालाश्च मनोज्ञाभिर्वाग्भिः सूर्यमिवर्षयः। एवं स्वशिबिरं प्रायाज्जित्वा शत्रून् धनंजयः॥ पृष्ठतः सर्वसैन्यानां मुदितो वै सकेशवः॥
English: And in a particular year produces one hundred times the merit (than gifts made at any other time). A gift made on the last day of the month produces inexhaustible merit. A gift made when the sun is on the solicit points, a gift made on the last day of the sun's path through Ubra, Asris, Gemini, Vrigo and Pisces and a gift made during the eclipses of the sun and the moon produce merits that are inexhaustible.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6688
Verse: 6688
Sanskrit: वज्रप्रवालस्फटिकैश्च मुख्यैः। चित्रे रथे पाण्डुसुतो बभासे नक्षत्रचित्रे वियतीव चन्द्रः॥
English: The learned men say that gifts made during the seasons produce merit that is ten times, those made during the change of seasons one hundred times and those made during the day when Rahu is visible one thousand times greater than what is produced at other times. A gift made on the last day of the sun's course though Libra and Aria produces merit that is everlasting.
---
Source: Itihasa

English: O king, no one can enjoy landed property who does not give away lands; no one can drive on cars and conveyances who does not give them away. With whatever, desire one gives away to the Brahmanas, one enjoys the fruition of that gift in the next birth.

Title: Verse 6691
Verse: 6691
Sanskrit: सम्ममर्द च तत् सैन्यं पिता देवव्रतस्तव। धान्यानामिव लूनानां प्रकरं गोगणा इव॥
English: There is nothing so everlasting as a gift. Is there any thing in the three worlds that is more auspicious? It is therefore that they who are greatly intelligent say that there is nothing higher in the three worlds than making gifts.

Title: Verse 6692
Verse: 6692
Sanskrit: धृष्टद्युम्नः शिखण्डी च विराटो द्रुपदस्तथा। भीष्ममासाद्य समरे शरैर्जघ्नुर्महारथम्॥
English: Yudhishthira said It is thus, on account of his Ignorance and his association with others who are invested with Ignorance, that Individual Soul passes through millions and millions of births every one of which has dissolution in the end.

Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6693
Verse: 6693
Sanskrit: धृष्टद्युम्नं ततो विध्वा विराटं च शरैस्त्रिभिः। दुपदस्य च नाराचं प्रेषयामास भारत॥
English: On account of his transformation into Intelligence invested with Ignorance, Individual Soul goes to millions of abodes, every one of which is liable to end in Jostruction, among intermediate beings and men and the gods.

Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6694
Verse: 6694
Sanskrit: तेन विद्धा महेष्वासा भीष्मेणामित्रकर्षिणा। चुक्रुधुः समरे राजन् पादस्पृष्टा इवोरगाः॥
English: On account of Ignorance, Individual Soul like the Moon, has to wax and wane thousands and thousands of times. This is truly the nature of Individual Soul when invested with Ignorance. Know that the Moon has in reality full sixteen portions. Only fifteen of these are subject to increase and decrease. The sixteenth remains constant. after the manner of the Moon, Individual Soul too has full appear and disappear. The sixteenth is subject to no change.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6695
Verse: 6695
Sanskrit: शिखण्डी तं च विव्याध भरतानां पितामहम्। स्त्रीमयं मनसा ध्यात्वा नास्मै प्राहरदच्युतः॥
English: Invested with Ignorance, Individual Soul repeatedly and continually takes birth in the fifteen portions, named above. With the etemai and immutable portion of Individual Soul the principal elements become united and this union takes place repeatedly.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6696
Verse: 6696
Sanskrit: धृष्टद्युम्नस्तु समरे क्रोधेनाग्निरिव ज्वलन्। पितामहं त्रिभिर्बाणैर्वाह्वोरुरसि चार्पयत्॥
English: That sixteenth portion is subtile. It should be known as Soma. It is never upheld by the senses. On the other hand, the senses are upheld by it.

Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6697
Verse: 6697
Sanskrit: द्रुपदः पञ्चविंशत्या विराटो दशभिः शरैः। शिखण्डी पञ्चविंशत्या भीष्मं विव्याध सायकैः॥
English: Since those sixteen portions are the cause of the birth of creatures, creatures can never, O king, take birth without their help. They are called Nature. The destruction of Jiva's liability to be united with nature is called Liberation.

Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6698
Verse: 6698
Sanskrit: सोऽतिविद्धो महाराज शोणितौघपरिप्लुतः। वसन्ते पुष्पशबलो रक्ताशोक इवाबभौ॥
English: The Principle of Greatness, which is the twenty-fifth, if it regards that body of sixteen portions called the Unmanifest, has to assume it repeatedly. On account of not knowing. That which is stainless and pure, and for its devotion to what is the outcome of a combination of both Pure and Impure, the Soul, which is, in reality, pure, becomes, O king, Impure. Indeed, on account of its devotion to ignorance, Individual soul though characterised by Knowledge, becomes repeatedly associated with Ignorance.
---
Source: Itihasa

English: Though, O king, free from error of every sort, yet on account of its devotion to the three qualities of Nature, it becomes endued with those attributes.

Title: Verse 6715
Verse: 6715
Sanskrit: नानादेशसमुत्थांतुरगान हेमभूषितान्। वातायमानानद्राक्षं शतशोऽथ सहस्रशः॥
English: Vaishampayana said : When the great Rishi was the mentioned, Bhishma with joined hands said. "That man is truly intelligent who fixes his eyes judiciously on Dharma, Artha and Kama and who, after reflecting with patience, acts in such a way as virtue (Dharma) may lead to future virtue, profit (Artha) to future profit and pleasure (Kama) to future pleasure. Therefore, that which has been said by you and that which, besides being beneficial to us is consistent with virtue, is certainly the best advice and it has my full approval."

Title: Verse 6716
Verse: 6716
Sanskrit: अश्वारोहान् हतैरश्चैर्ग्रहीतासीन् समन्ततः। द्रवमाणानपश्याम द्राव्यमाणांश्च संयुगे॥
English: Vaishampayana said : O descendant of the Kuru race, when Bhishma said this, Kali (Satyavati) thought of the Rishi Krishna Dvaipayana Dvaipayana, who was then interpreting the Vedas, came at once to his mother without any body knowing it, as soon as he found that he had been thought of. She (Satyavati), having welcomed her son in all due forms, embraced him with her arms and bathed him with her breast milk. The daughter of the fisherman (Satyavati) shed much tears to see her son after a long time.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6717
Verse: 6717
Sanskrit: गजो गजं समासाद्य द्रवमाणं महाहवे। ययौ प्रमृद्य तरसा पादातान् वाजिनस्तथा॥
English: Having seen her weep, the great Rishi, Vyasa, her eldest son, washed her (face) with cool water; and bowing to his mother, he said-
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6718
Verse: 6718
Sanskrit: तथैव च रथान् राजन् प्रममर्द रणे गजः। रथाश्चैव समासाद्य पतितांस्तुरगान् भुवि॥
English: O mother, I have come to fulfill your wishes. Therefore, o virtuous lady, command me without delay. I shall accomplish what you desire.”
The priest (of the Bharatas) then worshipped the great Rishi in the proper form and the Rishi accepted the offerings of the worship with uttering the usual Mantras.
Being pleased with the due worship with the proper Mantras, he took his seat. His mother, Satyavati, seeing him conformably seated, asked his welfare and made the usual enquiries.
She then said, O Kavi, (learned man), the sons derive their birth from both the father and the mother. There is no doubt that their proprietors are both the father and the mother. You are my eldest son according to the ordinances. O Brahmarshi, Vichitravirya was my youngest son. As he was the brother of Bhishma by father's side, so you are by the mother's side. This is my opinion, I do not know what is your opinion, I do not know what is your opinion. This Bhishma, the son of Shantanu, who is devoted to truth, does not, for the sake of truth, wish to beget children or to rule the kingdom.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6719
Verse: 6719
Sanskrit: व्यमृद्न् समरे राजंस्तुरगाश्च नरान् रणे। एवं ते बहुधा राजन् प्रत्यमृद्न् परस्परम्॥
English: Therefore, O sinless one, for the sake of the affection you bear for your brother (Vichitravirya), for the sake of perpetuating the dynasty of Shantanu, for the sake of Bhishma and my request. For the sake of the kindness you bear for all creatures, for the sake of the protection of people and for the sake of the liberality of your heart you should do what I say. Your younger brother has left two young wives, like the daughters of the celestials. They possess beauty and youth and they wish to have sons from the desire of getting virtue. O son, therefore, beget on them sons worthy of our dynasty and for the continuance of our line.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6720
Verse: 6720
Sanskrit: तस्मिन् रौद्रे तथा युद्धे वर्तमाने महाभये। प्रावर्तत नदी घोरा शोणितान्त्रतरङ्गिणी॥
English: Vyasa said: O (mother) Satyavati, you know what is virtue, both as regards this world and the next. O lady of great wisdom, your mind is also fixed on virtue. Therefore, making virtue my motive, I shall, at your command, do what you desire, knowing (as I do) that this practice is conformable to the true and eternal religion. I shall produce for my brother sons that will be like Yama and Varuna.
---
Source: Itihasa

Title: Verse 6727
Verse: 6727
Sanskrit: गुणवत्सु कथं द्वेषं धृतराष्ट्रो जनेश्वरः। कृतवान् पाण्डुपुत्रेषु पापात्मा लोभमोहितः॥
English: On account of my bad fate, the Bharata dynasty has become extinct. Seeing me grieved and the extinction of his paternal line. O beautiful girl, bring forth a son as effulgent as the king of the celestials. He will bear the heavy burden of our this hereditary kingdom.

English: Bhima then, with his deadly weapons and with great dexterity of hands, waging a ruthless slaughter amongst that body of troops, dispatched them to the region of Pluto.

Title: Verse 6806
Verse: 6806
Sanskrit: नाध्यापनाद् याजनाद् वा अन्यस्माद् वा प्रतिग्रहात्। दोषो भवति विप्राणां ज्वलिताग्निसमा द्विजाः॥
English: In that carnage blood flowed like water and the war-cars forming its eddies, elephants, its alligators, horses and men, its sharks and fishes and the hair of animals, its herbs and moss, were all floating on it. Arms severed from bodies floated like snakes and precious stones were abundant in the bloody current; thighs and marrows formed its gavials and mud and human heads, its mountain. Iron bound bludgeous and maces were also floating there like snakes, and bows and arrows formed its rafts by means of which persons tried to cross that fearful and bloody stream, banners and umbrellas drifted on it like swans and costly head-dresses its foam. The dust rising from the earth were like the waves of the stream and jeweled necklaces were looking like so many lotuses; the brave could alone cross that stream while the faint hearted sunk within to navigate it. That gushing current, with hands of sturdy soldiers forming its alligators and crocodiles, streamed its course towards the realm of Death. (and) and that man with tiger-like ferocity made its course flew on. (And) as the Vaitarani is unnavigable by persons of fifth and inequity, even so was that awful stream of blood to men wanting in valour and intrepidity, making their heart quail with shudder.
---
Source: Itihasa

English: Yudhishthira heard from his intelligencebearers that the horse had turned back. And hearing also that Arjuna was hale and hearty, he became filled with joy.

Title: Verse 6838
Verse: 6838

English: In the meantime, seeing that the twelfth day of the lighted fortnight in the month of Magha had come, and marking also that the constellation was favourable, high Yudhirshthira the just summoned all his brothers, viz., Bhima and Nakula and Sahadeva. Gifted with great energy, the king, o you of Kuru's race, that foremost of all persons knowing duties, said these words in proper time, Indeed, that foremost of all speakers, addressing Bhima, the first of all smiters, said,

Title: Verse 6875
Verse: 6875
Sanskrit: मातापित्रोः प्रजायन्ते पुत्राः साधारणाः कवे॥ तेषां पिता यथा स्वामी तथा माता न संशयः। विधानविहितः सत्यं यथा मे प्रथमः सुतः॥ विचित्रवीर्यो ब्रह्मर्षे तथा मेऽवरजः सुतः। यथैव पितृतो भीष्मस्तथा त्वमपि मातृतः॥ भ्राता विचित्रवीर्यस्य यथा वा पुत्र मन्यसे। अयं शान्तनवः सत्यं पालयन् सत्यविक्रमः॥ बुद्धिं न कुरुतेऽपत्ये तथा राज्यानुशासने। स त्वं व्यपेक्षया भ्रातुः संतानाय कुलस्य च॥
English: Kapila said The Vedas are considered as an authority by all. People never disobey them. Brahma is of two kinds, viz., Brahma is represented by sound, and Brahma as Supreme.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6876
Verse: 6876
Sanskrit: भीष्मस्य चास्य वचनानियोगाच्च ममानघ। अनुक्रोशाच भूतानां सर्वेषां रक्षणाय च॥ आनृशंस्याच यद् ब्रूयां तच्छुत्वा कर्तुमर्हसि। यवीयसस्तव भ्रातुर्भार्ये सुरसुतोपमे॥ रूपयौवनसम्पन्ने पुत्रकामे च धर्मतः। तयोरुत्पादयापत्यं समर्थो ह्यसि पुत्रक॥ अनुरूपं कुलस्यास्य संतत्याः प्रसवस्य च।
English: One conversant with Brahma of sound succeeds in attaining to Supreme Brahma. Beginning with the rites of Garbhadhana, that body which the father creates with the help of Vedic Mantras is purified (after birth) by Vedic Mantras.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6877
Verse: 6877
Sanskrit: व्यास उवाच वेत्थ धर्मं सत्यवति परं चापरमेव च॥ तथा तव महाप्राज्ञे धर्मे प्रणिहिता मतिः। तस्मादहं त्वन्नियोगाद् धर्ममुद्दिश्य कारणम्॥ ईप्सितं ते करिष्यामि दृष्टं ह्येतत् सनातनम्। भ्रातुः पुत्रान् प्रदास्यामि मित्रावरुणयोः समान्॥
English: When the body, has been purified with purificatary rites, the owner thereof is called a Prahmana and becomes a vessel fit for receiving knowledge of Brahma. Know that the meed of acts is purity of heart which only brings on Liberation. I shall now speak to you of that.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6878
Verse: 6878
Sanskrit: व्रतं चरेतां ते देव्यौ निर्दिष्टमिह यन्मया। संवत्सरं यथान्यायं ततः शुद्धे भविष्यतः॥ न हि मामव्रतोपेता उपेयात् काचिदङ्गना।
English: Whether purity of heart has been acquired or not, is what can be known to the person himself who has acquired it. It can never be known with the help of either the Vedas or inference. They who have no expectations, who discard every sort of riches by not keeping anything for future use, who are not covetous, and who are free from every sort of affection and aversion, celebrate sacrifices believing only that their performance is a duty. To make gifts to deserving persons is the end of all riches.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6879
Verse: 6879
Sanskrit: सत्यवत्युवाच सद्यो यथा प्रपद्येते देव्यौ गर्भं तथा कुरु॥ अराजकेषु राष्ट्रेषु प्रजानाथा विनश्यति। नश्यन्ति च क्रियाः सर्वा नास्ति वृष्टिर्न देवता॥
English: Never addicted at any time to sinful deeds, observant of rites sanctioned by the Vedas, capable of fructifying all their wishes, gifted with certain conclusions through pure knowledge, never giving way to anger,-never indulging in envy, free from pride and malice, firm in Yoga, of unsullied conduct, and unsullied learning, given to the behoof of all creatures, there were in days of yore many men living like householders and thoroughly devoted to the their own duties, there were many kings also of the same accomplishment, devoted to Yoga, and many Brahmanas also of the same character.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6880
Verse: 6880
Sanskrit: कथं चाराजकं राष्ट्र शक्यं धारयितुं प्रभो। तस्माद् गर्भ समाधत्स्व भीष्मः संवर्धयिष्यति॥
English: They treated all creatures equally and were gifted with perfect sincerity. They had contentiment, certainty of knowledge. The rewards of their righteousness were apparent, and they were pure in conduct and heart. They were endued with faith in Brahma of both forms.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6881
Verse: 6881
Sanskrit: व्यास उवाच यदि पुत्रः प्रदातव्यो मया भ्रातुरकालिकः। विरूपतां मे सहतां तयोरेतत् परं व्रतम्॥
English: At first making their hearts pure, they duly observed all vows. They observed the duties of righteousness on even occasions of distress and great difficulty, without deviating in any particular.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6882
Verse: 6882
Sanskrit: यदि मे सहते गन्धं रूपं वेषं तथा वपुः। अद्यैव गर्भ कौसल्या विशिष्टं प्रतिपद्यताम्॥
English: Uniting together they used to celebrate meritorious acts. In this they found great happiness. And inasmuch as they never transgressed, they had never to perform any expiatory rite.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6883
Verse: 6883
Sanskrit: वैशम्पायन उवाच एवमुक्त्वा महातेजा व्यासः सत्यवतीं तदा। शयने सा च कौसल्या शुचिवस्त्रा ह्यलंकृता॥ समागमनमाका दिति सोऽन्तर्हितो मुनिः। ततोऽभिगम्य सा देवी स्नुषां रहसि संगताम्॥ धर्म्यमर्थसपायुक्तमुवाच वचनं हितम्। कौसल्ये धर्मतन्त्रं त्वां यद् ब्रवीमि निबोध तत्॥
English: Depending upon the true course of virtue, they became gifted with irresistible energy. They never followed their own understandings while acquiring merit but followed the injunctions of the scriptures along for that end. Accordingly they were never guilty of guile in performing acts of righteousness.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6884
Verse: 6884
Sanskrit: भरतानां समुच्छेदो व्यक्तं मद्भाग्यसंक्षयात्। व्यथितां मां च सम्प्रेक्ष्य पितृवंशं च पीडितम्॥ भीष्मो बुद्धिमदान्मह्यं कुलस्यास्य विवृद्धये। सा च बुद्धिस्त्वय्यधीना पुत्रि प्रापय मां तथा॥ नष्टं च भारतं वंशं पुनरेव समुद्धर। पुत्रं जनय सुश्रोणि देवराजसमप्रभम्॥ स हि राज्यधुरं गुर्वीमुद्वक्ष्यति कुलस्य नः।
English: On account of their observing unitedly the perfect ordinances of the scriptures without following the rites laid down in the alternative, they were never compelled to perform any expiation.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6885
Verse: 6885
Sanskrit: सा धर्मतोऽनुनीयैनां कथंचिद् धर्मचारिणीम्। भोजयामास विप्रांश्च देवर्षीनतिथींस्तथा॥
English: There is no expiation for men who follow the ordinances laid down in the scriptures. The Shruti says that expiation exists for only men who are weak and unable to follow the absolute provisions of the sacred law.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6886
Verse: 6886
Sanskrit: वैशम्पायन उवाच अजिनानि विधु-वन्तः करकांश्च द्विजर्षभाः। ऊचुस्ते भीर्न कर्तव्या वयं योत्स्यामहे परान्॥
English: Many Brahmanas of this kind in days of yore, devoted to the celebration of Vedas, endued with purity, good conduct and fame.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6887
Verse: 6887
Sanskrit: तानेवं वदतो विप्रानर्जुनः प्रहसन्निव। उवाच प्रेक्षका भूत्वा यूयं तिष्ठथ पार्श्वतः॥
English: They always adored Brahma in the sacrifices, and were free from desire. Endued with learning they got over all the bonds of life. The sacrifices of these men, their Vedic knowledge, their acts performed according to the ordinances, their study of the scriptures at the proper hours, and the wishes they formed, freed as they were from lust and anger, observant as they were of pious conduct and acts despite all difficulties, famous as they were for performing the duties of their own castes and mode of life, purified as their souls were on account of their very nature, characterised as they were by thorough sincerity, devoted as they were to tranquillity, and attentive as they were to their own practises, were at one with Infinite Brahma. This is the eternal Shruti we have heard. The penances of men who were so noble, of men whose conduct and acts were so difficult of observance and accomplishment, of men those wishes were crowned with success on account of the strict satisfaction of their duties, became potent instruments for the destruction of all worldly desires. The Brahmanas hold that that Good conduct, which is wonderful, whose origin may be traced to very old times, which is eternal, and whose marks are unchangeable, which differs from the practices which even the good follow in time of distress and represents their acts in other situations, which is at one with carefulness, over which lust, anger, and other evil passions have no control, and on account of which there was no transgression in all mankind, subsequently became divided into four sub-divisions, agreeing with the four modes of life, by person unable to follow its duties in ininute detail and entirety.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6888
Verse: 6888
Sanskrit: अहमेनानजिह्मात्रैः शतशो विकिरज्छरैः। वारयिष्यामि संक्रुद्धान् मन्त्रैराशीविपानिव॥
English: By properly following that course of Good Conduct after adoption of the Sanyasa mode of life, the good attain to the highest end. They also who become forest recluses, reach the same high end.
---
Source: Itihasa

Title: Verse 6889
Verse: 6889
Sanskrit: इति तद् धनुरानम्य शुल्कावाप्तं महाबलः। भ्रात्रा भीमेन सहितस्तस्थौ गिरिरिवाचलः॥
English: They also who observe the domestic mode of life, attain to the highest end; and lastly, those who lead the Brahmacharya mode, attain to the same end. Those Brahmanas are seen to shine in the sky as luminaries shedding beneficent rays of light all around.

Title: Verse 6890
Verse: 6890
Sanskrit: ततः कर्णमुखान् दृष्ट्वा क्षत्रियान् युद्धदुर्मदान्। सम्पेततुरभीतौ तौ गजौ प्रतिगजानिव॥
English: Those countless Brahmanas have become stars and constellations set in their fixed roads. By virtue of contentment they have all acquired Infinity as the Vedas say.

Title: Verse 6891
Verse: 6891
Sanskrit: ऊचुश्च वाचः परुपास्ते राजानो युयुत्सवः। आहवे हि द्विजस्यापि वधो दृष्टो युयुत्सतः॥
English: If such men have to return to the world through the wombs of living creatures, they are never sullied by sins which have the unexhausted remnant of pristine deeds for their originating cause.

Title: Verse 6892
Verse: 6892
Sanskrit: इत्येवमुक्त्वा राजानः सहसा दुद्रुबुद्धिजान्। ततः कर्णो महातेजा जिष्णुं प्रति ययौ रणे॥
English: Indeed, one who has lived like a Brahmacharin and served dutifully his preceptor, who has arrived at fixed conclusions, and who has devoted hiinself to Yoga thus, is truly a Brahmana. Who else is worthy of being called a Brahmana?
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6893
Verse: 6893
Sanskrit: युद्धार्थी वासिताहेतोर्गजः प्रतिगजं यथा। भीमसेनं ययौ शल्य मद्राणामीश्वरो बली॥
English: When acts alone settle who is a Brahmana and who is not; acts must be held to point out the happiness or misery of a person. About those who have by conquering all evil passions acquired purity of heart, we have heard the eternal Shruti that, on account of the Infinity which they acquire and of the knowledge of Brahma (they acquire through the declarations of Shrutis), they see everything as Brahma. The duties followed by those pure-hearted men, who are shorn of desire, and who have Liberation only for their object, for acquisition of the knowledge of Brahma, are equally sanctioned for all the four castes and all the four modes of life. That knowledge is always gained by Brahmanas of pure hearts and controlled soul.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6894
Verse: 6894
Sanskrit: दुर्योधनादयः सर्वे ब्राह्मणैः सह संगताः। मृदुपूर्वमयत्नेन प्रत्ययुध्यंस्तदाहवे॥
English: One whose soul is for Renunciation based upon contentment, is considered as the refuge of true knowledge. Renunciation, wherein exists the knowledge leading to Liberation, and which is highly necessary for a Brahmana, is eternal.

Source: Itihasa

Title: Verse 6895
Verse: 6895
Sanskrit: ततोऽर्जुनः प्रत्यविध्यदापतन्तं शितैः शरैः। कर्णं वैकर्तनं श्रीमान् विकृष्य बलवद् धनुः॥
English: Renunciation is sometimes found mixed with the duties of other modes. But whether existing in that state or by itself, one practises it according to his power. Renunciation is the root of great benefit to every sort of person. Only he who is weak, fails to pursue it. That pure-hearted man who seeks to attain to Brahma becomes saved from the world.

English: Of them who are given up to enjoyment, they who make gifts, they who celebrate sacrifices, they who are given to the study of the Vedas, and they who follow the life of Renunciation after having acquired and enjoyed riches and all its pleasures, when they depart from this world, who is it who gets the foremost place in heaven? I ask you this, O

Title: Verse 6897

Sanskrit: तावुभावप्यनिर्देश्यौ लाघवाज्जयतां वरौ। अयुध्येतां सुसंरब्धावन्योन्यविजिगीषिणौ॥
English: Those who live like householders are surely auspicious and gain every sort of excellence. They are unable, however, to enjoy the happiness of Renunciation. Even you may see this.

Title: Verse 6900
Verse: 6900
Sanskrit: अर्जुनेन प्रयुक्तांस्तान् बाणान् वेगवतस्तदा। प्रतिहत्य ननादोच्चैः सैन्यानि तदपूजयन्॥
English: Kapila said-Acts only purify the body, Knowledge, however, is the highest end. When all defects of the heart are cured, and when the happiness of Brahma becomes established in knowledge. benevolence, forgiveness, tranquillity, mercy, truthfulness, and open-mindedness, abstention from injury, absence of pride, modestry, renunciation, and abstention from work are acquired.

Source: Itihasa

English: These form the path of Brahma. By those one acquires the Highest. A wise man when he acquires these qualities, understands that the cure of all defects of the heart is the result of acts.

Title: Verse 6905
Verse: 6905
Sanskrit: वैशम्पायन उवाच तमेवं वादिनं तत्र फाल्गुनः प्रत्यभाषत। नास्मि कर्ण धनुर्वेदो नास्मि रामः प्रतापवान्॥
English: This is the one conclusion of all the scriptures viz., that this universe exists and does not exist. To the man of knowledge this is both existent and non-existent. To him this all is both the end and the middle.

Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6906
Verse: 6906
Sanskrit: ब्राह्मणोऽस्मि युधां श्रेष्ठः सर्वशस्त्रभृतां वरः। ब्राह्मे पौरंदरे चास्त्रे निष्ठितो गुरुशासनात्॥
English: This truth depends upon all the Vedas, viz., that when complete Renunciation takes place one acquires what is sufficient. Then, again, the highest contentment follows and depends upon Liberation, which is absolute, which exists as the soul of all moral and immortal things, which is well-known as such universal soul, which is the highest object of knowledge as being at one with all mobile and immobile objects, which is full, which is perfect happiness, which is without duality, which is the foremost of all things, which is Brahma, which is Unmanifest and the cause also of the Unmanifest, and which is without any sort of decay.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6907
Verse: 6907
Sanskrit: स्थितोऽस्म्यद्य रणे जेतुं त्वां वै वीर स्थिरो भव। एवमुक्तस्तु राधेयो युद्धात् कर्णो न्यवर्तत॥
English: Power to control the senses, forgiveness and abstention from work owing to the absence of desire,-these three are the cause of perfect happiness. With the help of these three qualities, men having understanding for their eyes, succeed in reaching that Brahma which is increate, which is the supreme cause of the universe, which is unchangeable, and which is beyond destruction. I bow to that Brahma, which is at one with him that knows it.
---
Source: Itihasa

Title: Verse 6909
Verse: 6909
Sanskrit: बलिनौ युद्धसम्पन्नौ विद्यया च बलेन च। अन्योन्यमाह्वयन्तौ तु मत्ताविव महागजौ॥
English: Why have you then taken this rash step such as this vow of starvation? Suicide always leads (a man) to hell. It becomes the subject of calumnious speech.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6910
Verse: 6910
Sanskrit: मुष्टिभिर्जानुभिश्चैव निघ्नन्तावितरेतरम्। प्रकर्षणाकर्षणयोरभ्याकर्षविकर्षणैः॥
English: Intelligent men like you never engage in acts that are sinful and opposed to their best interests and which strike at the very root of their purposes.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6911
Verse: 6911
Sanskrit: आचकर्षतुरन्योन्यं मुष्टिभिश्चापि जघ्नतुः। ततश्चटचटाशब्दः सुघोरो ह्यभवत् तयोः॥
English: O king, therefore restrain your this resolve. It is destructive of morality, profit and happiness and of fame, prowess and energy. It enhances the joy of one's enemies.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6912
Verse: 6912
Sanskrit: पाषाणसम्पातनिभैः प्रहारैरभिजघ्नतुः। मुहूर्तं तौ तदान्योन्यं समरे पर्यकर्षताम्॥ ततो भीमः समुक्षिप्य बाहुभ्यां शल्यमाहवे। अपातयत् कुरुश्रेष्ठो ब्राह्मणा जहसुस्तदा॥ तत्राश्चर्यं भीमसेनश्चकार पुरुषर्षभः। यच्छल्यं पातितं भूमौ नावधीद् बलिनं बली॥
English: O king, of lord, know the truth, the celestials origin of your birth and the make up of your body; and then assume patience.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6913
Verse: 6913
Sanskrit: पातिते भीमसेनेन शल्ये कर्णे च शरूिते। शरूिताः सर्वराजानः परिवर्तृकोदरम्॥
English: O king, in the days of yore, we obtained you from Maheshvara by ascetic austerities. The upper part of your body is wholly made of Vajra (thunder).
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6914
Verse: 6914
Sanskrit: ऊचुश्च सहितास्तत्र साध्विमौ ब्राह्मणर्षभौ। विज्ञायेतां क्वजन्मानौ क्वनिवासौ तथैव च॥
English: On sinless one, therefore it is invincible to weapons of every description. The lower part of your body, capable of captivating the female heart by its comeliness, was made of flowers by the goddess herself.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6915
Verse: 6915
Sanskrit: को हि राधासुतं कर्णं शक्तो योधयितुं रणे। अन्यत्र रामाद् द्रोणाद्वा पाण्डवाद्वा किरीटिनः॥
English: O foremost of kings, thus your body was created by Ishvara himself and the goddess. Therefore, O best of kings, your origin is celestials and not human.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6916
Verse: 6916
Sanskrit: कृष्णाद् वा देवकीपुत्रात् कृपाद् वापि शरद्वतः। को वा दुर्योधनः शक्तः प्रतियोधयितुं रणे॥
English: Other greatly powerful Kshatriyas headed by Bhagadatta, all learned in the celestials weapons, will kill your enemies.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6917
Verse: 6917
Sanskrit: तथैव मद्राधिपति शल्यं बलवतां वरम्। बलदेवादृते वीरात् पाण्डवाद् वा वृकोदरात्॥ वीराद् दुर्योधनाद् वान्यः शक्तः पातयितुं रणे। क्रियतामवहारोऽस्माद् युद्धाद् ब्राह्मणसंवृतात्॥
English: Therefore there is not need for you grief. You have no cause for fear. In order to help you, many heroic Danavas have been born on earth.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6918
Verse: 6918
Sanskrit: ब्राह्मणा हि सदा रक्ष्याः सापराधापि नित्यदा। अथैनानुपलभ्येह पुनर्योत्स्याम हृष्टवत्॥ तांस्तथावादिनः सर्वान् प्रसमीक्ष्य क्षितीश्वरान्। अथान्यान् पुरुषांश्चापि कृत्वा तत् कर्म संयुगे॥
English: Other Asura will possess Bhishma, Drona and Karna and others. Possessed by the Asuras, those heroes will cast away their kindness and fight with your enemies.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6919
Verse: 6919
Sanskrit: वैशम्पायन उवाच तत् कर्म भीमस्य समीक्ष्य कृष्ण: कुन्तीसुतौ तौ परिशरूमानः। निवारयामास महीपतींस्तान् धर्मेण लब्धेत्यनुनीय सर्वान्॥
English: When the Danavas will enter their heart and completely possess them flinging all affection to a distance and becoming hard-hearted, those heroes will then strike every one opposed to them without sparing sons, brothers, fathers, friends, disciples, relatives, even children and old men.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6920
Verse: 6920
Sanskrit: एवं ते विनिवृत्तास्तु युद्धाद् युद्धविशारदाः। यथावासं ययुः सर्वे विस्मिता राजसत्तमाः॥
English: Blinded by ignorance and wrath and impelled by destiny which has been ordained by the creator, those foremost of men with hearts steeped in sin will. O foremost of the Kurus, depopulate the earth by hurling all kinds of weapons with great manliness and strength and always boastfully addressing one another with words such as these, “You will not escape from me today with life.” The five illustrious sons of Pandu will fight with these (heroes).
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6921
Verse: 6921
Sanskrit: वृत्तो प्रह्मोत्तरो रङ्गः पाञ्चाली ब्राह्मणैर्वृता। इति ब्रुवन्तः प्रययुर्ये तत्रासन् समागताः॥
English: Possessing great strength and favoured by the fate, they would bring about the destruction of all. Many Daityas and Yakshas, that have been born in the Kshatriya order, will fight with great prowess in battle with your enemies using maces, clubs, lances and various weapons.
---
Source: Itihasa

Title: Verse 6922
Verse: 6922
Sanskrit: ब्राह्मणैस्तु प्रतिच्छन्नौ रौरवाजिनवासिभिः। कृच्छ्रेण जग्मतुस्तौ तु भीमसेनधनंजयौ॥
English: O hero, as for the fear of Arjuna in your heart, we have already settled the means of killing Arjuna.

Title: Verse 6923
Verse: 6923
Sanskrit: विमुक्तौ जनसम्बाधाच्छत्रुभिः परिवीक्षितौ। कृष्णयानुगतौ तत्र नृवीरौ तौ विरेजतुः॥ पौर्णमास्यां घनर्मुक्तौ चन्द्रसूर्याविवोदितौ। तेषां माता बहुविधं विनाशं पर्यचिन्तयत्॥
English: The soul of the killed Naraka has assumed the form of Karna. Recollecting. O hero, his former enmity, he will kill both Keshava (Krishna) and Arjuna.

English: That great car-warrior, that foremost of all wielders of weapons, proud of his prowess, will vanquish Arjuna in battle, as also all your enemies.

English: The wielder of thunder (Indra), knowing all this and desirous of saving Savyasachi (Arjuna), will in disguise take away from Karna his ear-rings and armour.

Title: Verse 6926
Verse: 6926
Sanskrit: इत्येवं चिन्तयामास सुतस्नेहावृता पृथा। ततः सुप्तजनप्राये दुर्दिने मेघसम्प्लुते॥ महत्यथापराहणे तु घनैः सूर्य इवावृतः। ब्राह्मणैः प्राविशत् तत्र जिष्णुर्भार्गववेश्म तत्॥
English: We have therefore appointed hundreds upon hundreds and thousands upon thousand of Daityas and Rakshasas; they are known by the name of Samshaptakas.

Title: Verse 6927
Verse: 6927
Sanskrit: संजय उवाच श्रुत्वा तु रथनिर्घोषं सिंहनादं च संयुगे। अर्जुनः प्राह गोविन्दं शीघ्र नोदय वाजिनः॥
English: These illustrious warriors will kill the heroic Arjuna. Do not therefore grieve. O king, you will rule the whole earth without a rival.

Title: Verse 6928
Verse: 6928
Sanskrit: अर्जुनस्य वचः श्रुत्वा गोविन्दोऽर्जुनमब्रवीत्। एष गच्छामि सुक्षिप्रं यत्र भीमो व्यवस्थितः॥
English: Do not give way to despondency. O descendant of Kuru, this conduct does not suit you. If you die, our party will become weak.

Title: Verse 6929
Verse: 6929
Sanskrit: तं यान्तमश्चैर्हिमशङ्खवणैः सुवर्णमुक्तामणिजालनद्धैः। जम्भं जिघासुं प्रगृहीतवज्रं जयाय देवेन्द्रमिवोगमन्युम्॥
English: O hero, go, you should never direct your mind in any other course. You are our refuge.

English: Bhishma, Drona, Kripa and others, their mind possessed by the Danavas. O king, were not so affectionate towards the Pandavas as they were before. The king Suyodhana did not tell this to any one.

English: At the end of the night, the son of the sun, Karna, thus smilingly spoke to Duryodhana with joined hands.

Title: Verse 6941

Sanskrit: तेऽर्जुन सहिता भूत्वा रथवंशैः प्रहारिणः। अभियाय महेष्वासा विव्यधुर्निशतैः शरैः॥
English: “No dead man can conquer his foes, it is when he is alive that he can see his good. Where is the good of the dead person and O descendant of Kuru, where is his victory?

Title: Verse 6947
Verse: 6947
Sanskrit: तां तु सेनां भृशं विद्ध्वा द्रावयित्वार्जुनः शरैः। प्रायादभिमुखः पार्थः सूतानीकं हि मारिष॥
English: Having heard the words of the Daityas, that foremost of men with a firm resolve in his heart arrayed his army full of horses, elephants, chariots and foot soldiers. O king, as it moved on like the waters of the Ganga.

Title: Verse 6948
Verse: 6948
Sanskrit: तस्य शब्दो महानासीत् परानभिमुखस्य वै। गरुडस्येव पततः पन्नगार्थे यथा पुर॥
English: With numerous white umbrellas and pennons and white Chamaras and chariots and elephants and foot soldiers that great army, as is moved on like the waters of the Ganga looked as beautiful as the sky at a season when the clouds have been dispersed and the signs of autumn have been but partially developed.

Title: Verse 6949
Verse: 6949
Sanskrit: तं तु शब्दमभिश्रुत्य भीमसेनो महाबलः। भभूव परमप्रीतः पार्थदर्शनलालसः॥
English: O king of kings, eulogised as a monarch by the foremost of Brahmanas who all prayed for his victory, that king, Suyodhana, the son of Dhritarashtra, received honours paid to him by innumerable men) with joined hands.

Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6950
Verse: 6950
Sanskrit: श्रुत्वैव पार्थमायान्तं भीमसेनः प्रतापवान्। त्यक्त्वा प्राणान् महाराज सेनां तव ममर्द ह॥
English: Blazing in great splendour he went in front (of the army) accompanied by Karna, Subala's son, the gambler (Shakuni), Dushashana and all his other brothers, Bhurishrava, Somadatta, the great king Bahlika followed that foremost of kings with various sorts of chariots, horses and excellent elephants. O foremost of kings, within a short time all those perpetuators of the Kuru race entered their own city.

Title: Verse 6951
Verse: 6951
Sanskrit: स वायुवीर्यप्रतिमो वायुवेगसमो जवे। वायुवद् व्यचरद् भीमो वायुपुत्रः प्रतापवान्॥
English: Ashtaka said: Those that are learned in the Vedas differ in opinions as regards the respective methods which should be practised by the Grihastas, Brahmacharis, Bhikshus and Vanaprasthas, so that they may acquire religious merits.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6952
Verse: 6952
Sanskrit: तेनार्धमाना राजेन्द्र सेना तव विशाम्पते। व्यभ्रश्यत महाराज भिन्ना नौरिव सागरे॥
English: Yayati said: A Brahmachari must do the following. When he will live in the house of his preceptor, he must receive lessons only when his preceptor will call him to do it. He must serve his preceptor without waiting for his command. He must rise before his preceptor from his bed and go to bed after him. He must be humble, self-controlled, patient, vigilant and devoted to study.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6953
Verse: 6953
Sanskrit: तां तु सेनां तदा भीमो दर्शयन् पाणिलाघवम्। शरैरवचकतॊग्रैः प्रेषयिष्यन् यमक्षयम्॥
English: It is said in the oldest Upanishad that he must perform sacrifices after acquiring wealth by honest means. He should spend it in charity; he should be hospitable to all that would come to his house; he should never use anything without giving a portion to others.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6954
Verse: 6954
Sanskrit: तत्र भारत भीमस्य बलं दृष्ट्वाऽतिमानुषम्। व्यभ्रमन्त रणे योधाः कालस्येव युगक्षये॥
English: A Muni (Brahmachari) should live in the forest, depending on his own vigour and without searching for food. He should abstain from all vicious acts; he should give away in charity; he should never inflict pain upon any creatures. It is then only that he can gain success.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6955
Verse: 6955
Sanskrit: तथादितान् भीमबलान् भीमसेनेन भारत। दृष्ट्वा दुर्योधनो राजा इदं वचनमब्रवीत्॥ सैनिकांश्च महेष्वासान् योधांश्च भरतर्षभ। समादिशन् रणे सर्वान् हत भीममिति स्म ह॥
English: He is a true Bhikshu, who does not support himself by any manual labour, who possesses many accomplishments, who has his passions under complete control, who is thoroughly unconnected with all worldly concerns, who does not sleep under the shelter of a householder's roof, who is without wife and who travels over many countries, going some distance every day.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6956
Verse: 6956
Sanskrit: तस्मिन् हते हतं मन्ये पाण्डुसैन्यमशेषतः। प्रतिगृह्य च तामाज्ञां तव पुत्रहस्य पार्थिवाः॥ भीमं प्रच्छादयामासुः शरवर्षेः समन्ततः।
English: A learned should adopt the Vanaprastha mode of life, after the performance of the necessary rites. He should adopt it when he has been able to control his thirst for enjoyments and desire of acquiring wealth. When a man dies in the forest, leading the Vanaprastha mode of life, he mixes his ancestors and grand-children, numbering ten generations including himself, with the divine man essence.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6957
Verse: 6957
Sanskrit: गजाश्च बहुला राजन् नराश्च जयगृद्धिनः॥ रथे स्थिताश्च राजेन्द्र परिवब्रुर्वृकोदरम्।
English: Ashtaka said : How many kinds of Munis are there and how many kinds of Munis (observers of vows)? We desire to hear all this.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6958
Verse: 6958
Sanskrit: स तैः परिवृतः शरैः राजन् समन्ततः॥ शुशुभे भरतश्रेष्ठो नक्षत्रैरिव चन्द्रमाः।
English: Yayati said: O king, he is a true Muni, who possesses all things pertaining to a village though living in the forest and also possesses all things pertaining to the forest though living in a village.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6959
Verse: 6959
Sanskrit: परिवेषी यथा सोमः परिपूर्णो विराजते॥ स रराज तथा संख्ये दर्शनीयो नरोत्तमः। निर्विशेषो महाराज यथा हि विजयस्तथा।॥
English: Ashtaka said : How is it possible to possess all things pertaining to a village when living in the forest and all things pertaining to a forest when living in a village?
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6960
Verse: 6960
Sanskrit: तस्य ते पार्थिवाः सर्वे शरवृष्टिं समासृजन्। क्रोधरक्तेक्षणाः शूरा हन्तुकामा वृकोदरम्॥
English: Yayati said : A Muni lives in the forest after withdrawing himself from all worldly objects. But though he never seeks to possess things pertaining to a village, he may yet get them by his ascetic powers.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6961
Verse: 6961
Sanskrit: तां विदार्य महासेनां शरैः संनतपर्वभिः। निश्चकाम रणाद् भीमो मत्स्यो जालादिवाम्भसि॥३७
English: A true Muni, withdrawn from all earthly objects, might live in a village, leading the life of a hermit. Chad in Kaupina (scantiest of robes,) he considers himself attired in the richest robe. He is content with food just sufficient to support life. He who abandons all desires, who has all his passions under complete control and who has given up all actions, is the man who attains success.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6962
Verse: 6962
Sanskrit: हत्वा दशसहस्राणि गजानामनिवर्तिनाम्। नृणां शतसहस्रे द्वे द्वे शते चैव भारत॥ पञ्च चाश्वसहस्राणि रथानां शतमेव च। हत्वा प्रास्यन्दयद् भीमो नदी शोणितवाहिनीम्॥
English: Why should you not revere the man who lives on pure food, who refrains from injuring others, whose heart is ever holy, who is effulgent in his ascetic merits, who is free from the leaden weight of desire and who abstains from injury even when it is sanctioned by the scriptures?
---
Source: Itihasa

Title: Verse 6963
Verse: 6963
Sanskrit: शोणितोदां रथावर्ता हस्तिग्राहसमाकुलाम्। नरमीनाश्वनक्रान्तां केशशैबलशाद्वलाम्॥ संछिन्नभुजनागेन्द्रां बहुरत्नापहारिणीम्। ऊस्याहां मजपङ्का शीर्षोपलसमावृताम्॥ धनुष्काशां शरावापां गदापरिधकेतनाम्। हंसच्छत्रध्वजोपेतामुष्णीषवरफेनिलाम्॥ हारपद्माकरां चैव भूमिरेणूर्मिमालिनीम्। आर्यवृत्तवतां संख्ये सुतरां भीरुदुस्तराम्॥ योधग्राहवतीं संख्ये वहन्तीं यमसादनम्। क्षणेन पुरुषव्याघ्रः प्रावर्तयत निम्नगाम्॥ यथा वैतरणीमुग्रां दुस्तरामकृतात्मभिः। तथा दुस्तरणी घोरां भीरूणां भयवर्धिनीम्॥
English: Emaciated by hard asceticism and reduced in marrow, blood and flesh, such a Muni not only conquers this world, but the highest world.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 6964
Verse: 6964
Sanskrit: यतो यतः पाण्डवेयः प्रविष्टो रथसत्तमः। ततस्ततोऽघातयत योधाशतसहस्रशः॥
English: The Muni who sits in Yoga mediation and who becomes indifferent to happiness and misery, honour and insult, conquers this world and conquering it, he conquers the highest world.

Title: Verse 6991

Sanskrit: स हि तेषां महावीर्यो द्वीपोऽभूत सुमहाबलः। भिन्ननौका यथा राजन् द्वीपमासाद्य निर्वृताः॥ भवन्ति पुरुषव्याघ्र नाविकाः कालपर्यये। तथा कर्णं समासाद्य तावकाः पुरुषर्षभ॥ समाश्वस्ता: स्थिता राजन् सम्प्रहृष्टाः परस्परम्। समाजग्मुश्च युद्धाय मृत्यु कृत्वा निवर्तनम्॥
English: Seeing the kine run towards the city of Matsya's and considering Kiritin successful, the heroic Kurus all on a sudden withstood him who was proceeding towards Duryodhana.

Verse: 7032
Sanskrit: कपिल उवाच वेदाः प्रमाणं लोकानां न वेदाः पृष्ठतः कृताः। द्वे ब्रह्मणी वेदितव्ये शब्दब्रह्म परं च यत्॥
English: Ignorant as I am, give me wisdom like a learned preceptor to his pupil or like a father to his son. Be pleased with ine, O Shaunaka!
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 7033
Verse: 7033
Sanskrit: शब्दब्रह्मणि निष्णातः परं ब्रह्माधिगच्छति। शरीरमेतत् कुरुते यद् वेदे कुरुते तनुम्॥
English: Shaunaka said What wonder is there that an ignorant wight should do many improper acts? Knowing this, a really wise person is never angry with foolish creatures.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 7034
Verse: 7034
Sanskrit: कृतशुद्धशरीरो हि पात्रं भवति ब्राह्मणः। आनन्त्यमत्र बुद्ध्यदं कर्मणां तद् ब्रवीमि ते॥
English: By getting upon the top of wisdom's palace, one grieves for others, his own self being then too pure to be grieved by others. For his wisdom one surveys all creatures in the world like a person on a mountain-top seeing people below.

Title: Verse 7035
Verse: 7035
Sanskrit: अनागममनैतिचं प्रत्यक्षं लोकसाक्षिकम्। धर्म इत्येव ये यज्ञान् वितन्वन्ति निराशिषः॥ उत्पन्नत्यागिनोऽलुब्धाः कृपासूयाविवर्जिताः। धनानामेष वै पनास्तीर्थेषु प्रतिपादनम्॥
English: The person who is censured by good men, who hates good men and who hides himself from their view, never acquires any blessing and never understands the fitness of acts.

Title: Verse 7036
Verse: 7036
Sanskrit: अनाश्रिताः पापकर्म कदाचित् कर्मयोगिनः। मन:संकल्पसंसिद्धा विशुद्धज्ञाननिश्चयाः॥ अक्रुध्यन्तोऽनसूयन्तो निरहङ्कारमत्सराः। ज्ञाननिष्ठास्त्रिशुक्लाश्च सर्वभूतहिते रताः॥ आसन् गृहस्था भूयिष्ठा अव्युत्क्रान्ताः स्वकर्मसु। राजानश्च तथा युक्ता ब्राह्मणाश्च यथाविधि॥
English: You know the energy and the nobility of the Brahmana as laid down in the Veda and other scriptures. Act now in such a way that you may have tranquillity of heart and let Brahmanas be your refuge. If the Brahmanas do not be angry with you, you will, forsooth, enjoy happiness in heaven. If, again, you repent for sins, your sight will be clear and you will succeed in seeing righteousness.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 7037
Verse: 7037
Sanskrit: समा ह्यार्जवसम्पन्नाः संतुष्टा ज्ञाननिश्चयाः। प्रत्यक्षधर्माः शुचयः श्रद्दधानाः परावरे॥
English: Janamejaya said, I am repenting for my sins. I will never again try to suppress virtue. I wish to obtain blessedness. Be you pleased with me.

Title: Verse 7040
Verse: 7040
Sanskrit: सत्यं हि धर्ममास्थाय दुराधर्षतमा मताः। न मात्रामनुरुध्यन्ते न धर्मच्छलमन्ततः॥

Title: Verse 7041
Verse: 7041
Sanskrit: य एव प्रथमः कल्पस्तमेवाभ्याचरन् सह। तेषां नासीद् विधातव्यं प्रायश्चित्तं कदाचन॥
English: They will even call me sinful. My kinsmen and friends will renounce me. However, hearing the words I speak, my kinsmen and friends will surely succeed in vigorously crossing the difficulties of life.

Title: Verse 7042
Verse: 7042
Sanskrit: तस्मिन् विधौ स्थितानां हि प्रायश्चित्तं न विद्यते। दुर्बलात्मन उत्पन्न प्रायश्चित्तमिति श्रुतिः॥
English: The wise will understand me aright. Know, O child, what are my views, O Bharata, regarding the Brahmanas. Do you act in such a way that they may, through my efforts, obtain every blessing! Do you also, O king, promise that you will not again injure the Brahmanas.

Sanskrit: श्रूयतां तु प्रभो तत्त्वं दिव्यतां चात्मनो नृप। निर्माणं च शरीरस्य ततो धैर्यमवाप्नुहि॥
English: Then the Kaikeya General Ugrakarman, seeing the Kaikeyas prince thus killed rushed on towards Karna and moving forward his bow repeatedly began to distress Karna's son Prasena with many powerful shafts.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 7070
Verse: 7070
Sanskrit: पुरा त्वं तपसास्माभिर्लब्धो राजन् महेश्वरात्। पूर्वकायश्च पूर्वस्ते निर्मितो वलासंचयैः॥
English: Then Karna, with three crescent-like shafts, severed his head and arms from the body and like a Sala tree cut down by an axe he (Ugrakarman) fell down lifeless from his car.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 7071
Verse: 7071
Sanskrit: अस्त्रैरभेद्यः शस्त्रैश्चाप्यधः कायश्च तेऽनघ। कृतः पुष्पमयो देव्या रूपतः स्त्रीमनोहरः॥
English: Then Prasena, if dancing with excitement, assailed the steedless grandson of Shini (Satyaki) with many straight arrows, by was in return killed by the grandson of Shini.
---
Source: Itihasa

Title: Verse 7072
Verse: 7072
Sanskrit: एवमोश्वरसंयुक्तस्तव देहो नृपोत्तम। देव्या च राजशार्दूल दिव्यस्त्वं हि न मानुषः॥
English: Karna, filled with vengeance at the death of his son and wishing to slay that foremost of Shinis addressed him, “consider yourself a dead man" and struck him with a deadly arrow.

Title: Verse 7073
Verse: 7073
Sanskrit: क्षत्रियाच महावीर्या भगदत्तपुरोगमाः। दिव्यास्त्रविदुषः शूराः क्षपयिष्यन्ति ते रिपून्।॥
English: as But Shikhandin severed that arrow with three shafts and with three other distressed Karna; then the wrathful son of Suta with two razor-like shafts struck off the bows, arrows and banners of Shikhandi.

Title: Verse 7074
Verse: 7074
Sanskrit: तदलं ते विषादेन भयं तव न विद्यते। साहाय्यार्थं च ते वीराः सम्भूता भुवि दानवाः॥
English: With six other powerful arrows hit Shikhandi himself and killed Dhristadyumna's son; and the noble son of Adhiratha also struck Sutasoma with a very sharp arrows.

Title: Verse 7075
Verse: 7075
Sanskrit: भीष्मद्रोणकृपादींश्च प्रवेक्ष्यन्त्यपरेऽसुराः। यैराविष्टा घृणां त्यक्त्वा योत्स्यन्ते तव वैरिभिः॥
English: O most powerful of monarchs, in that terrible fight loud lamentations were heard as the son of Dhristadumnya fell down and Krishna, hearing that, addressed Partha and said, “Partha go and kill Karna for he is destroying the whole Panchala race."

Title: Verse 7076
Verse: 7076
Sanskrit: नैव पुत्रान् न च भ्रातृन् न पितॄन् न च बान्धवान्। नैव शिष्यान् न च ज्ञातीन् न बालान् स्थविरान् न च।। युधि सम्प्रहरिष्यन्तो मोक्ष्यन्ति कुरुसत्तम। नि:स्नेहा दानवाविष्टाः समाक्रान्तेऽन्तरात्मनि॥
English: Then in order to save the Panchalas from the fear of that great car-warrior, Karna, he (Arjuna) advanced on his car towards the chariot of the son of Adhiratha with a smile in his lips.

Title: Verse 7077
Verse: 7077
Sanskrit: प्रहरिष्यन्ति विवशा: स्नेहमुत्सृज्य दूरतः। हृष्टाः पुरुषशार्दूला: कलुषीकृतमानसाः। अविज्ञानविमूढाश्च दैवाच्च विधिनिर्मितात्॥ व्याभाषमाणाश्यान्योन्यं न मे जीवन् विमोक्ष्यसे सर्वे शस्त्रास्त्रमोक्षेण पौरुषे समवस्थिताः॥ श्लाघमानाः कुरुश्रेष्ठ करिष्यन्ति जनक्षयम्। तेऽपि पञ्च महात्मानः प्रतियोत्स्यन्ति पाण्डवाः॥
English: Then rubbing his palm on the bow-string with a very loud twang he stretched out the Gandiva and suddenly made the Earth look dark by covering the sun with showers of arrows and also killed hosts of men, horses and elephants and destroyed many banners.
---
Source: Itihasa

Title: Verse 7078
Verse: 7078
Sanskrit: वधं चैषां करिष्यन्ति दैवयुक्ता महाबलाः। दैत्यरक्षोगणाश्चैव सम्भूताः क्षत्रयोनिषु॥ योत्स्यन्ति युधि विक्रम्य शत्रुभिस्त्व पार्थिव। गदाभिर्मुसलैः शूलैः शस्त्रैरुच्चावचैस्तथा॥
English: At that fearful moment, when Kiritin (the diadem-decked Arjuna) greatly excited, with the Gandiva in his hands, bent almost to a circle, assailed his enemies the loud twang of his bow resounded through the skies and the birds being afraid took refuge in caves and mountains.

English: The redoubtable Bhimasena followed Arjuna on his car guarding the rear and both the princes fighting their way on their respective cars advanced fast towards Karna.

English: In the meantime the son of Suta had been fighting terribly-he repeatedly thrashed the Somakas and and killed killed large numbers of elephants, horses and car-warriors; in fact he covered the atmosphere with his shafts.

English: As ship-wrecked merchants are saved from drowning in a deep sea by means of other ships, so did the sons of Draupadi, with the help of their cars, save their maternal uncles from sinking under the pressure of Karna's weapons who resembled the sea.

Verse: 7102
Sanskrit: गते त्रयोदशे वर्षे सत्येनायुधमालभे। आनयिष्याम्यहं पार्थान् वशं तव जनाधिप॥
English: Markandeya said : Mudita, the favourite wife of the fire named Svaha, live in water. Svaha who was the lord of the sky, begot on his that wife a greatly sacred fire named Adbhuta. Title: Verse 7103
Verse: 7103
Sanskrit: एवमुक्तस्तु कर्णेन दैत्यानां वचनात् तथा। प्रणिपातेन चाप्येषामुदतिष्ठत् सुयोधनः॥
English: That fire is adorable and effulgent, he is the lord of all the Bhutas here. And that fire under the name of Grihapati is always worshipped at all sacrifices and conveys all the oblations that are made in this world.

English: That mighty chief fire (Svaha) is always missed by the celestials, for when he sees Niyata coming towards him, he hides himself in the sea for fear.

Title: Verse 7107
Verse: 7107
Sanskrit: कर्णेन सार्धं राजेन्द्र सौबलेन च देविना। दुःशासनादयश्चास्य भ्रातरः सर्व एव ते॥ भूरिश्रवाः सोमदत्तो महाराजश्च बाह्निकः। स्थैर्नानाविधाकारैर्हयैर्गजधरैस्तथा॥ प्रयान्तं नृपसिंहं तमनुजग्मुः कुरूद्वहाः। कालेनाल्पेन राजेन्द्र स्वपुरं विविशुस्तदा॥
English: Seeing him in every direction, the celestials could not find him out and seeing Atharvan, the fire thus spoke to him.

Title: Verse 7108
Verse: 7108
Sanskrit: अष्टक उवाच चरन् गृहस्थः कथमेति धर्मान् कथं भिक्षुः कथमाचार्यकर्मा। वानप्रस्थः सत्पथे संनिविष्टो बहून्यस्मिन् सम्प्रति वेदयन्ति॥
English: O hero, carry the oblations for the celestials. I am unable to do it for the want of strength. Becoming the red-eyed fire, be good enough to do me this favour.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 7109
Verse: 7109
Sanskrit: ययातिरुवाच आहूताध्यायी गुरुकर्मस्वचोद्यः पूर्वोत्थायी चरमं चोपशायी। मृदुर्दान्तो धृतिमानप्रमत्तः ध्यायशील: सिध्यति ब्रह्मचारी॥
English: Having thus spoken to Atharvan, the fire went away to some other place. But his place of concealment was divulged by the fish, Upon them he passed this course in anger.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 7110
Verse: 7110
Sanskrit: धर्मागतं प्राप्य धनं यजेत दद्यात् सदैवातिथीन् भोयजेच्च। अनाददानश्च परैरदत्तं सैषा गृहस्थोपनिषत् पुराणी॥
English: You shall be the food of all creatures in various ways." Then the fire spoke to Atharvan (again as he did before).
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 7111
Verse: 7111
Sanskrit: स्ववीर्यजीवी वृजिनान्निवृत्तो दाता परेभ्यो न परोपतापी। तादृङ्मुनिः सिद्धिमुपैति मुख्यां वसन्नरण्ये नियताहारचेष्टः॥
English: Though entreated by the celestials, he did not agree to continue to carry the oblations. He then became insensible and abandoned his body.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 7112
Verse: 7112
Sanskrit: अशिल्पजीवी गुणवांश्चैव नित्यं जितेन्द्रियः सर्वतो विप्रयुक्तः। श्चरन् देशानेकचरः स भिक्षुः॥
English: Leaving his material body, he entered into the nether world. Coming in contact with the earth, he created different force and perfume arose from his puss, the Deodar tree from his bones, grass from this phlegm, the Marakata jewel from his bile and the black iron from his liver. All the worlds have been established with these three substances. The clouds were made from his nails and corals from his arteries,
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 7113
Verse: 7113
Sanskrit: रात्र्या यया वाभिजिताच लोका भवन्ति कामाभिजिताः सुखाचा नरण्यसंस्थो भवितुं यतात्मा॥ दशैव पूर्वान् दश चापरांश्च ज्ञातीनथात्मानमथैकविंशम्। अरण्यवासी सुकृते दधाति विमुच्यारण्ये स्वशरीरधातून्॥
English: O King, various other metals were produced from his body. Thus leaving his material body, he lay absorbed in meditation.

Title: Verse 7114
Verse: 7114
Sanskrit: अष्टक उवाच कतिस्विदेव मुनयः कति मौनानि चाप्युत। भवन्तीति तदाचक्ष्व श्रोतुच्छिामहे वयम्॥
English: He was roused by the penance of Bhrigu and Angirasa. The mighty Agni, thus gratified by their penance, blazed forth in great effulgence.

Title: Verse 7115
Verse: 7115
Sanskrit: ययातिरुवाच अरण्ये वसतो यस्य ग्रामो भवति पृष्ठतः। ग्रामे वा वसतोऽरण्यं स मुनिः स्याजनाधिप॥
English: But seeing the Rishi, he in fear again entered the great ocean. When he thus disappeared, all the worlds were filled with fear and came to Atharvan for protection. The celestials and others then began to adore Atharvan.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 7116
Verse: 7116
Sanskrit: अष्टक उवाच कथंस्विद् वसतोऽरण्ये ग्रामो भवति पृष्ठतः। ग्रामे वा वसतोऽरण्यं कथं भवति पृष्ठतः॥
English: Atharvan overhauled the whole sea and (at last) finding Agni, he himself (then) began the creation. Thus the fire was destroyed and rescued from the sea. thus was he revived by the exalted Atharvan; and thus from that time he always carries the oblations of all creatures.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 7117
Verse: 7117
Sanskrit: ययातिरुवाच न ग्राम्यमुपयुञ्जीत य आरण्यो मुनिर्भवेत्। तथास्य वसतोऽरण्ये ग्रामो भवति पृष्ठतः॥
English: Living in the sea and travelling in various countries, he produced the various fires mentioned in the Shastras.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 7118
Verse: 7118
Sanskrit: अनग्निरनिकेतश्चाप्यगोत्रचरणो मुनिः। कौपीनाच्छादनं यावत् तावदिच्छेच चीवरम्॥ यावत् प्राणाभिसंधानं तावदिच्छेच भोजनम्। तथास्य वसतो ग्रामेऽरण्यं भवति पृष्ठतः॥ यस्तु कामान् परित्यज्य त्यक्तकर्मा जितेन्द्रियः। आतिष्ठेच मुनिर्मीनं स लोके सिद्धिमाप्नुयात्॥
English: The river Sindhu, the five rivers, the Devika, the Sarasvati, the Ganga, the Shatakumbha, the Sarayu, the Gandaki, the Charmnavati, the Mahi, the Medhya, the Medhatithi, the three rivers Tamravati, the Vetravati, the Kaushiki, the Tamasa, the Narmada, the Godavari, the Vena, the Upavena, the Bhima, the Vadava, the Bharati, the Suprayoga, the Kaveri, the Murmura, the Tungavena, the Krishnavena, the Kapila and the Sonabhadra, these rivers are said to be the mothers of the fires.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 7119
Verse: 7119
Sanskrit: धौतदन्तं कृत्तनखं सदा स्नातमलंकृतम्। असितं सितकर्माणं कस्तमर्हति नार्चितुम्॥
English: Adbhuta had a wife named Priya and Vibhurasi was his eldest son. There are as many kinds of Soma sacrifices as the number of fires mentioned. All these fires were first born from the spirit of Brahma, but they also sprung from the race of Atri.

English: He in his own mind conceived these sons in order to extend the creation. These fires all sprung from his Brahmic body.

English: I have thus narrated to you the history of the origin of the (different) fires. They are great, effulgent and matchless in prowess; and they are the destroyer of darkness.

English: O descendant of Kuru, O best of men, like the king of birds (Garuda), he rushed upon Dvarka, with his army, equipped with every kind of weapons, skilled in all arms, furnished with numerous chariots, elephants and cavalry, full of pennons and banners and strengthened with well-paid, well-fed and greatly powerful foot soldiers who bore every mark of heroism and who used wonderful chariots and bows.

Title: Verse 7133
Verse: 7133
Sanskrit: प्रमदाभ्यो वरा सा तु सत्त्वरूपगुणान्विता। ततः प्रमद्वरेत्यस्या नाम चक्रे महानृषिः॥
English: O best of the Bharata race, as Indra shower down rain, so did the son of Jambhavati (Samba) showers down arrows in a continuous stream. O great king, the commander of (Shalva's) forces, Kshemavriddhi, bore that shower of arrows (and stood) as immovable as the Himalayas.

Sanskrit: तेषामनीकानि बहूनि गाढं व्यूढानि दृष्ट्वा बहुलध्वजानि। मत्स्यस्य पुत्रं द्विषतां निहन्ता वैराटिमामन्त्र्य ततोऽभ्युवाच॥
English: O descendant of Kuru, Pradyumna sallied out and asked the Anarthas not to lose courage. He then thus spoke.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 7150
Verse: 7150
Sanskrit: एतेन तूर्णं प्रतिपादयेमान् श्वेतान् हयान् काञ्चनरश्मियोक्त्रान्। जवेन सर्वेण कुरु प्रयत्नमासादयेऽहं कुरुसिंहवृन्दम्॥
English: (O warriors), do not lose courage; stay and see me fight. I shall repel with force (the car) Saubha with the king (Shalva) on it.
O Yadavas, I shall this day destroy the army of the lord of Saubha with my serpent-like weapons discharged from my bow with my hand.
Be of good cheer, Fear not. I shall today kill him. Attacked by me, the wicked-minded (Shalva) with (his car) SAubha will be destroyed.
---
Source: Itihasa
Category: Mahabharata
Title: Verse 7151
Verse: 7151
Sanskrit: गजो गजेनेव मया दुरात्मा योद्धं समाकाङ्क्षति सूतपुत्रः। तमेव मां प्रापय राजपुत्र दुर्योधनापाश्रयजातदर्पम्॥
English: O son of Pandu, O hero, when Pradyumna thus spoke with a cheerful heart, the Yadava warriors stood on the field and began to fight cheerfully.
---
Source: Itihasa

English: Bhishma said That best of all persons conversant with the Vedas, viz., Utatthya of Angirasa's family, discoursed gladly to Yuvanashva's son Mandhatri.

Title: Verse 7154
Verse: 7154
Sanskrit: ततः स तेषां पुरुषप्रवीरः शरासनार्चिः शरवेगतापः। वातं रथानामदहत् समन्युर्वनं यथाग्निः कुरुपुङ्गवानाम्॥
English: Utatthya said One becomes a king for advancing the cause of virtue and not for acting capriciously. Know this, O Mandhatri; the king is, indeed, the protector of the world.

Title: Verse 7155
Verse: 7155
Sanskrit: तस्मिंस्तु युद्धे तुमुले प्रवृत्ते पार्थ विकर्णोऽतिरथं रथेन। विपाठवर्षेण कुरुप्रवीरो भीमेन भीमानुजमससाद॥
English: If the king acts piously, he attains to the dignity of a god. If, however, he acts unrighteously, he sinks into hell.

Title: Verse 7156
Verse: 7156
Sanskrit: ततो विकर्णस्य धनुर्विकृष्य जाम्बूनदाङ्मयोपचितं दृढज्यम्। च्छिन्नध्वजः सोऽप्यपयाज्ज्वेन।॥
English: All cri itures depends upon righteousness. Righteousness again depends upon the king. men That king, therefore, who maintains righteousness, is truly a king, that king who has a pious soul and posseses every kind of accomplishments is said to be an embodiment of virtue. If a king fails to punish iniquity, the god leave his palace and he incurs disreputation among men.
---
Source: Itihasa

Title: Verse 7157
Verse: 7157
Sanskrit: तं शात्रवाणां गणबाधितारं कर्माणि कुर्वन्तममानुपाणि। शत्रुतपः पार्थममृष्यमाण: समार्दयच्छर वर्षेण पार्थम्॥
English: The endeavours of men who observe their own duties are always successful. Therefore all try to obey the injunctions of righteousness which yield prosperity.

Title: Verse 7158

English: When sin is not restrained righteousness disappears and unrighteousness multiplies itself.

Title: Verse 7159
Verse: 7159
Sanskrit: ततः स विद्धो भरतर्षभेण बाणेन गात्रावरणातिगेन। गतासुराजौ निपपात भूमौ नगो नगाग्रादिव वातरुग्णः॥
English: When sin is not restrained, no one can, in view of the rights of property as sanctioned by the scriptures, say,-This thing is mine and this is not mine.

Verse: 7160

English: When sinfulness reigns rampant in the world, men cannot own and enjoy their own wives and animals and fields and houses.

Sanskrit: तास्तु पार्थेन नरप्रवीरा गतासवोर्त्यां सुषुपुः सुवेषाः। वसुप्रदा वासवतुल्यवीर्याः पराजिता वासवजेन संख्ये॥

Sanskrit: चचार संख्ये विदिशो दिशश्च दहन्निवाग्निर्वनमातपान्ते। प्रकीर्णपर्णानि यथा वसन्ते विशातयित्वा पवनोऽम्बुदांश्च॥
English: When sin is not restrained, the minds of men, O king, become weak and bewildered like those of persons wounded with weapons.

Title: Verse 7165
